title: Trump Says North Korea Summit Meeting May Be Delayed
author: By MARK LANDLER
summary: At a meeting with South Korea's president, Moon Jae-in, President Trump raised doubt about his planned meeting with North Korea's leader, Kim Jong-un. "It may not work out for June 12," he said. Mr. Trump expressed continued enthusiasm for the prospect, but acknowledged that statements by North Korea had cast a pall of uncertainty over it.

title: If Kim Keeps Nuclear Arms, Can Trump Still Claim Victory?
Meeting Is Yet to Come, but U.S. Has Minted the Coins
Abrams Wins Georgia Primary for Governor, Making History
author: By JONATHAN MARTIN and ALEXANDER BURNS
summary: Stacey Abrams is the first black woman to be a major party's nominee for governor. Ms. Abrams, a Democrat, will test just how much the state's conservative politics are shifting, and whether a black woman can win in the Deep South.

title: Amy McGrath Wins Democratic Primary for Kentucky's 6th District
Congress Approves First Big Rollback of Dodd-Frank Law
author: By ALAN RAPPEPORT and EMILY FLITTER
summary: The bipartisan legislation will now head to President Trump, leaving fewer than 10 big banks subject to stricter post-crisis oversight.

title: Trump Denies Reaching Deal on Chinese Telecom Firm ZTE
Cohen's Business
author: By DANNY HAKIM, WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and VIVIAN WANG
summary: After pleading guilty to tax evasion, a business partner of Michael D. Cohen, President Trump's lawyer, will cooperate as a potential witness. The development could be used as leverage to pressure Mr. Cohen to work with the special counsel.

title: Cohen and Russia-Tied C.E.O. Bonded, but Made No Deals
author: By BEN PROTESS, WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and MIKE McINTIRE
summary: Mr. Cohen's $1 million contract with an oligarch-linked investment firm yielded little in the way of deals. But he and the firm's chief became closely connected in business and fund-raising.

title: Can Paul Ryan Make It Through to January as House Speaker?
author: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG, THOMAS KAPLAN and NICHOLAS FANDOS
summary: Mr. Ryan pledged to finish out his term when he announced his retirement. But with Republicans in revolt on both his right and his left, he is stuck in the middle, with no clear path forward.

title: Want to Hold Your Newborn Baby? First Settle Your Bill
author: By SUI-LEE WEE
summary: A hospital in China demanded that a woman pay her bills before she could see her newborn twins, illustrating a plight that many face in the country's medical system.

title: Plan to Fix New York City's Subway Has $19 Billion Price Tag
author: By EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS
summary: The subway's new leader, Andy Byford, is expected to announce the expensive modernization plan on Wednesday to quickly upgrade the signal system.
The New York Times sat down with Philip Roth in 2011 to talk about his life and accomplishments.

title: Philip Roth, Master of American Letters, Is Dead at 85
author: By CHARLES McGRATH
summary: Mr. Roth won almost all the major literary awards and published an exceptional sequence of historical novels in his 60s, an age when many writers are winding down. Comments

summary: Here's what you need to know at the end of the day.

summary: Here's what you need to know to start your day.

title: How to Spot and Overcome Your Hidden Weaknesses
author: By TIM HERRERA
summary: We're generally pretty awful at assessing our skills. But there's hope.

title: How to Help People Who Need It More Than They Know
author: By ROB WALKER
summary: It took forever to find a qualified candidate for an opening. Now the new guy is struggling and resists supervision. How can he be reined in and guided toward success?

title: Is This the World's Most Diverse National Park?
author: By JAMES GORMAN
summary: Bringing the numbers to life at Madidi National Park, the jewel in Bolivia's conservation crown.

title: The Football Hit Felt All Over Japan
author: By KEN BELSON
summary: A linebacker apologized after he violently tackled a defenseless quarterback, saying his coaches told him to do it. It has highlighted the obedience to authority that is highly valued in Japan.

title: Britain's Red Phone Box Stages a Comeback
author: By PALKO KARASZ
summary: Once unwanted relics, the booths are being retooled in imaginative ways, including as cellphone repair shops, tiny cafes and defibrillator sites.  Comments

title: Film Breaks Silence for Betty Davis, a Raw Funk Pioneer
author: By JON PARELES
summary: For a few years in the 1970s, she was a trailblazing singer, bandleader and producer. A new documentary, "Betty: They Say I'm Different," tells her story.

title: New Cancer Treatments Lie Hidden Under Paperwork
author: By GINA KOLATA
summary: Guideposts to powerful treatments may be buried in medical records. But there is no easy way to gather them or to get them into a usable format.

title: Nixon Has the Buzz, but Cuomo May Have the Advantage
author: By SHANE GOLDMACHER
summary: For Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, the New York Democratic convention underscores how the party's traditional machinery, including Hillary Clinton, supports him over Cynthia Nixon.

title: Denmark Minister Calls Fasting Muslims 'a Danger'

summary: Start your summer planning with our new limited-run newsletter. The weekly guide will spotlight New York City's coolest summer activities. Food and drink included.

summary: Here's what you need to know to start your day.

title: With Senator's Snub, Australia Gets Stood Up by U.S. -- Again
summary: Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee declined to become the ambassador, just weeks after President Trump's previous choice was reassigned. Should Australia be taking this personally?

title: In Australia, Fears of Chinese Meddling Rise on U.N. Bribery Case Revelation
summary: An Australian politician identified Chau Chak Wing, an Australian citizen of Chinese descent, as a co-conspirator in a 2015 bribery case.

title: A D.I.Y. Trip Through Alaska's Inside Passage
summary: Following in the footsteps of John Muir -- and millions of modern cruise ship passengers -- one marine ferry at a time.

title: That Food-Stand Job Is No Longer Just for Teenagers
summary: An adolescent rite of passage has become an opportunity for foreign workers, and a challenge for employers.

title: The Skeleton in My Closet
summary: Keeping a human skull in a closet felt wrong and I wasn't about to display it in my curio cabinet.

title: With Senator's Snub, Australia Gets Stood Up by U.S. -- Again
author: DAMIEN CAVE
contents: SYDNEY, Australia -- Australia's hankering for a United States ambassador hit another snag on Tuesday when Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee announced that he had turned down the job."At the end of the day, I just felt like it wasn't the right fit and I still had work to do in the Senate," Senator Corker, a Republican, Talk about rejection. It was the second "no, not me" in less than a month. In April, President Trump withdrew the nomination of , the head of the Pacific Command, assigning him instead to South Korea.Australians have been reeling ever since.Why? From Australia's perspective, this isn't the first offense. And Australia is not just any ally.Let us explain.*Sigh*It's complicated.First there was , in which President Trump yelled at Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull about a refugee deal he hated.Then there was a warm exchange . That was followed by in Washington, which was quickly undone by President Trump's steel tariffs (he hates us!), which were later reversed with an exemption for Australia (he loves us!).One more cloud hovering over the relationship: One of Australia's senior diplomats into Russian meddling in the 2016 election.Actually, dozens of American embassies around the world do not have an ambassador.According to the State Department's latest report, 63 of 188 ambassadorships are vacant, including countries with histories of close ties to the United States, such as Ireland, Saudi Arabia and Turkey.Nobody puts Australia in the corner!Australia prides itself on a historic relationship with the United States.Soldiers from the two countries have fought and died alongside each other since World War I. Australia is also a key player in Five Eyes, an intelligence alliance with the United States, Canada, Britain and New Zealand."Australians feel that they are by and large very important, and surely the U.S. views us as very consequential," said John Blaxland, a professor of international security and intelligence studies at the Australian National University.Americans tend to agree, especially those in President Trump's own party. In a survey of Americans last year, Republicans said .The reality is that with other powers like China, Russia and North Korea confronting the United States, Australia is a bit player, a friend the Americans know they can invite out for dinner and then stand up."The perception emerging is that, well, maybe Trump doesn't care," Professor Blaxland said. "Maybe it doesn't matter in his calculus."Right now, the fort is being held by the charge d'affaires, James Carouso. Mr. Carouso, who after the last ambassador's departure in September 2016, has the same diplomatic duties and protections as an ambassador.But he lacks some of the protocols -- and, most importantly, the status that comes with the title.Former Prime Minister Kevin Rudd has as a sign that "Australia, from President Trump's perspective, is a second-class ally."Historically, the position has been filled by career diplomats during periods in which the United States is concerned about developments in Australia, said Professor Blaxland. In more relaxing times, the position has been a reward to presidential benefactors.Right now, though, no one seems to know what message Mr. Trump is sending. Senator Corker with the president, leading some to speculate that he was offered the job in Australia to banish him from Washington.Is there a strategy at all, some are asking, or just chaos? "The criticism is mounting," Professor Blaxland said.Some Australians are calling for Mr. Carouso to get the official nod.We asked readers, and a few prominent Australians, for their recommendations. * "If Ellen DeGeneres is in any way inclined toward retirement or producing her show in a different time zone, I'm sure her Australian wife would love a homecoming," said Benjamin Law, the gay Australian author, essayist and screenwriter. "After all, comedy can be a form of diplomacy, and us queers excel at international relations."* Alison Lowe, a New York Times reader in Australia, requested "someone fleet-footed at dodging potential pitfalls, whether animal, arachnid, marine, culinary or diplomatic.""Scrap that," she added, "just send Jon Stewart."* Andy Griffiths, the best-selling children's book author , told us he was sympathetic to anyone offered the post, given the politics of Canberra: "I reckon Bob Corker took one look at the invitation and thought it would be like jumping out of the frying pan into the fire," he said.* Ronny Chieng, a comedian on "The Daily Show," suggested Nicole Kidman, but later concluded that he, himself, was the best choice. "Nobody will be tougher on Australia than me," he said.
